c.1899 -

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Interesting to compare the two photos, isn't it?  This one is earlier - no tram poles etc.  Flags and Sunday best clothes - Anniversary Day? (Australia Day).

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: No Fire Station - it's earlier than I thought.  More like c.1890 ...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Certainly pre-1891 - the Manly Jetty seen in the other photo was built in 1891.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Thank you for the image and pointing out those clues. We initially dated this as c 1890 based on the women's clothing, however, the State Records NSW photograph provides a better reference point. Thanks again!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] I think your initial date of c.1890 is about right.  If someone could read the name of that ship,  we should be able to find the exact date with the Holiday.

" . . LLAROI." ??

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] It must be YALLAROI! Look at the photos to the side.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] GREAT!  'YALLAROI' it is.  The sister ship 'Torridon' rang a bell with me.  She/it was at the same mooring at Circular Quay for Anniversary Day 1888.  I previously thought this might have been the 'Torridon',  but here the 'Yallaroi' has a pale painted hull.  See comments etc here - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2362661905/]

A-troving to find a likely date ....

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Ha! Sometimes it is too easy - I Troved for "yallaroi circular quay holiday", and the first newspaper result was this for the SMH Thursday 18 September 1889 p.6 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13745086
" ... ... Today (Thursday) having been proclaimed a Government holiday, the Custom House will be closed ... ... ... ... To morrow the ship Yallaroi will vacate her discharging berth at the Circular Quay, and will bring up to an anchorage in the stream. ... ... "
I think the "Government holiday" was proclaimed for the opening of the Agricultural Society's Show.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] beachy's gone to NLA troving, for we don't know when we are ... Well, we do now, great result! And hats off to [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] for your fashion sense - your original date estimation of c.1890 was not far off the mark at all.

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: The harbour is clearly a very rich location for Flickr Commons images, as you can see in my new interactive Flickr Commons map - www.whatsthatpicture.com/flickr/commons-map.php?lon=16832...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/whatsthatpicture] James, I've been meaning to ask - any way of incorporating geo-tagged images of non-Commons members such as [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/] State Records NSW?

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Hi Ben, there's an 'unofficial' way I've just implemented to show any user's photos e.g. yours is www.whatsthatpicture.com/flickr/commons-map.php?lon=14666... (but just watch out for the current bug which means images fail to load if the map view spans the +-180 meridian). But I know that's not what you're asking here ... It would be fairly easy (I think) to have another users images displayed as an additional overlay, but what would be more difficult would be having images from a list of several selected users, which is certainly what I'd like to see. But this takes me back to another thought I'd already had, and that is to add a layer which displays images from my Geotagged Vintage Photographs group - www.flickr.com/groups/geotagged-vintage/ Then we just have to encourage everyone to add stuff there!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/whatsthatpicture] Ha! That map is so revealing. We urban Aussies do like to huddle in the south-east corner of the continent!

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/whatsthatpicture] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] We've joined your group :)

AB

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Yes, YALLAROI was known for her white painted hull. Check out this article where a boy tells of his experience with his beloved YALLAROI. Hmmmm, the YALLAROI was in port a lot in Sydney, that makes it hard to date exactly. But based on your research and the research of others including [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] we could go with either 1889 or 1890...right? Ha! It gets confusing.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] And thank you for your comments regarding fashion, it is in my area of interest and I'm trying hard to research more about fashion history. It's a great way to date photographs! Nicole, Curatorial assistant.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/whatsthatpicture] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] We love this idea of having one place to go to for all geo-tagged vintage pics. Great work! We joined too :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] That's a great article, thank you. It mentions A. HALL & Co., Aberdeen as the ship's builder. I wonder, just wonder, if they were related to the Halls photographers with their persistent interest in sailing? The ADB gives William Frederick Hall (father) as a "butcher from England" and a fingerprint expert - adb.anu.edu.au/biography/hall-william-james-10396

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Hmmmm, Hall was a common name so we think it is unlikely they were connected. Have you seen this report on the building? The thing that convinced me that it was it were the windows and how they are structurally placed close together, like in the photo. We are constantly amazed at how you spot the tiny details. :-)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Golly that report is detailed, and good to know about.  I had thought before that the 'CAMEO' building under construction here was Evans Store - my mistake,  it has a gabled roof and is further to the right (see note).  Pellethepoet is investigating CAMEO's real name and building date,  which should correspond with 1889 - fingers crossed.  Unfortunately it is not still there,  so won't be on Heritage websites.  C19th NSW builders had a useful habit of slapping the date at the top somewhere,  for flickeroonies to find 130 years later.  The CAMEO building was in two parts seen better in these two photos.  It always amuses me that they advertised "Germea for breakfast" to ferry passengers travelling into the city in the morning,  and the "Evening News" for those travelling out in the afternoon.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4625663728/]

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4350240764/]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: From the other end of Harrington Street - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4886823514/] and the Germea adverts on the two buildings seen from Harrington Lane - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4993877097] Interesting 1893 comparison, with the 'Cameo' rooftops crammed with spectators - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/4289987600/] Unfortunately no names for the buildings behind the English Scottish & Australian Chartered Bank and Police Station in this 1889 map - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367459.html

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Okay, I might have the name of the 'Cameo' building fronting Harrington Street. After consulting the large resolution of State Records' The Rocks - resumption plan, 1901 on Archives Investigator, and straining my eyes, it would appear to be no. 30/32. In a 1907 City of Sydney assessment book, we find the following details for this address - Control: CSA027343, Record Item: 17/6/24 | Ward: Gipps | Year: 1907 | Page: 10 | Number of Assessment Book: 192 | No. of House: 30/32 | Situation: Harrington Street | Name of Person Rated: Wong On Jang | Name of Landlord or Owner of Property: NSW Govt Rocks Resumption | House, Warehouse or Shop: Dyers Building | Brick, Stone, Wood or Iron: Brick | Slated, Shingled or otherwise: Iron | No. of Floors: 3 | No. of Rooms: 60 | Gross Annual Value in Pounds: £299 - www3.photosau.com/CosRates/Spreadsheets/1907/1907_GIPPS_W... In a 1911 assessment book, it was named in the plural as "Dyers' Buildings" - assessmentbooks.cityofsydney.s3.amazonaws.com/CRS17%20187... I'll leave the a-troving to you!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Brilliant as always - I know you enjoyed that! Dyers Buildings it is. Trouble is it was not originally called that. In 1891 the Dyer's Buildings were advertised for mortgagee sale presumably named for Mr Dyer who had a grocery there. Fascinating full details of the buildings in the SMH of 27/5/1891 p.10, column 6, first item "By order of the mortgagees ..." - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13825800 . Still looking for the building date ...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Hmm - from the SMH 3/6/1889 p.12, column 1, 4 items up from bottom - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13723867
" TO CARTERS, - TENDERS are invited for Removing the Debris of old buildings in Harrington-street, at the rear of A. J. S. Bank, George-st., Circular Quay. ... ... "
It's the wrong bank name - a misprint? There were not many banks between Harrington and George streets. I think it is possible to go from 'debris' in June to third floor by September in 1889. Q. E. D. ?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] What a wonderful description of the layout of the two Dyer's Buildings! And I agree, it must be a misprint. The advert surely should have read E. S. & A. Bank. The A. J. S. [Australian Joint Stock] Bank was on the corner of George and King Streets at the time, nowhere near Harrington! I wonder if any tenderers went to examine the debris at the wrong address and were left scratching their heads! So could be late 1889, but could still be 1890. Which is a little narrower than 1889-1890 but not much!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: SMH 8/3/1890 p.21, column 3, half-way down - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13762316 "SHOPS to LET, Dyer's Buildings, Harrington-street; low rent. Apply J. Dyer, George-street." It just got a little narrower!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
I would say that is enough information to confirm the completion date of the Dyers Building as 1890, and this photo as September 1889.  

Phew!

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] 
Oh wow you should see our collection database entry for this image now! It is overflowing with all of this fantastic information, we love the way you guys set to the images like a puzzle to solve. Nice work & thanks again!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Our pleasure! Just found an extraordinary list of the general cargo the 'Yallaroi' imported in August 1889 - asbestos to sardines and everything in between! Makes you realize how very little was manufactured in Australia - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13735521

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Just saw this last comment, thanks for the link. Such a simple list can yield so much information! The other thing that is striking is how much was carried on these vessels.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
